image I used to sort of capture this is an image that if you're of a certain age you will definitely remember this ad if

because I refer to this as the Charlie complex because this is what I thought
life was like I thought that as you grew up this is just what happened to you
you've got this really this was attractive in the 1970s you got you got this really nice pants suit
you got a great hair do you looked gorgeous and you're all you obviously just off to some fabulous job there was

but it was it was Shelly hack as well in an even nicer outfit with a better briefcase and a daughter or at least a
very pretty little blonde girl by her side so the Assumption there was that you're going to work you're going to
leave the kids somewhere which presumably has good child care and you're going to waltz off to the job and the kids's going to be fine and and Life
as we know it is just perfect this is what I thought the world was like and this is what I think many ambitious
smart women of my generation presumed that we would just Walt into the professional world and everything would
just work out and to some extent it was true and I think that's sort of what
defined my career throughout the early years and then all of a sudden it kind of hit me that was different that life
wasn't going to be like the Charlie commercial and that in fact the sheer fact of my gender was going to be an
issue and that realization really came to me when I was a junior faculty member at HBS and as we were just talking I
speaking with some of you be you know before this presentation I think that's still true here that it's different
being a woman on the faculty than it is being a man just as it's different being a young woman at most investment Banks
than it is being a man and I suddenly became more and more intrigued by this
question of what were the differences between being a professional woman and being a professional man as I sort of
survived longer and longer here I was more often asked to help solve the
woman's problem and would sort of be called into office and saying Deb we need you to kind of solve the woman's thing and I
became slowly convinced of two things first of all that there was a woman's problem which I had been actively
denying all of my career up until that point I really became convinced that there was a woman's problem and secondly
and more importantly that it wasn't an easy problem to fix that there were no
switches that could be flicked or policies that could be passed that would
just solve the women's problem and I a number of us in the room
spent many years and I know many people are still struggling with this now to solve the women's problem which is not
specific to HBS it exists just about everywhere but I think we all were
realizing that it was just a more difficult problem to address because to
some extent the first wave feminists had done what in retrospect was the easier
part they had changed the policies they had changed the rules they opened up HBS
to women and we were left now with a subtler set of problems that could
couldn't be addressed by regulation alone so just as I was sort of struggling through these thoughts um and
beginning the early stages of what would become this book I left HBS and I moved to Barnard and all women's college and I
underwent what I now refer to as a massive hormonal shift because I left this place which in all due respect has
a fair amount of testosterone floating around and all of a sudden I moved to barard where is one of my loved former
colleagues would have said you can't find testosterone with a search party and you can't it's a very female
place and one of the things that I realized sort of immediately and then took more time to think through it was
that organizations run by women in my opinion are fundamentally different than
organizations run by men they're not better they're just different they feel
different meetings run differently people are hired differently people are fired differently arguments get fought
in a very different way and so I really started to spend some time thinking
about and and eventually researching what was it that made women run
organizations different than mail run organizations and what might we do by by
sort of trying to think about these differences in in a productive way and what I eventually have become convinced
of is Ju Just to repeat brief that the women's problem today is much
more subtle than it was in the time of the Charlie complex we no longer face
problems around rules and regulations I don't think we Face problems based in
Prejudice I really don't I think just about every man I've seen whether it's running this place running investment
Banks running major corporations they really want to solve the women's problem they just don't know really what it is
much less how to do it and and I don't blame them I mean it's it's a tough problem and I and I think there's it's
not Prejudice I don't think thankfully we Face a situation anymore where men are trying to stop women from advancing
I think quite the contrary it's just that we don't know how to fix these issues I also think and
I'll talk a little bit more about this later I think we need to Grapple with the fact that some of the differences
between men and women and and Men run and women run organizations exist in
this little discussed thing called biology um we have kind of
overlooked the basic underlying biological differences between between
men and women that play out in some very very important ways that we don't really

began convinced mostly from watching my friends my colleagues and my students
that women's lives just play out differently that even if a woman and a man started the same point they've just

hearing stories from my friends and particularly from barard alums from HBS

some of women's problems stem from their own our own
expectations expectations more specifically that have been generated by

blasted continuously at us by the media and carved into our psyches nearly from

fail which is why expectations is such an important topic um that runs through

millions of American women so we inherited a set of expectations that at the moment are

177% of the Senate 16% of the house all stuck in this kind of

top of the pyramid the even worse news is that 30 years ago you could have

still see this situation across industry uh industry
sectors why I will throw out four hypotheses I will not give you my
preferred one at the moment but I will throw them out there for subsequent case method discussion um the first is what
what I would call embedded discrimination and this is really really subtle but I see it all the time that

make partner who to promote who to give a big award to they tend to just move towards people
other than women they just are not in the Consciousness unless somebody says

has been chosen then it's like they've done the woman thing and then you can move on and
it'll be interesting now we have a number of Ivy League presidencies open whether places that had their first
woman now go go back or whether there's some sense and you pend did do this that you know you can actually have two women
in a row um but many times and I you know I I really do see this all the time
there's a sense as once you have one woman you're kind of off the hook forgetting anymore a second piece and
again I say this all the time and I think it's really interesting and people should be doing more work on this there
is an inclination for replication we all think that we are
really good and therefore that the people who are most like us are liable
to be really good as well and I didn't quite realized this until I got to
barard because what I barard replicates as much as HBS does so if HBS is is run
by middle-aged white guys they will tend to see younger white guys as the most
likely leaders Barner is run by middle-aged Jewish ladies so we're always looking for the next generation
of young Jewish lady you know but we we replicate um and my my husband caught me
doing exactly the same thing recently I was describing one of my who I described
as one of my best faculty members and I was just you know waxing eloquent about her many talents my husband said you do
realize you were describing yourself you know that oh she's young she's high energy she has brown hair you know it
was I I had sort of fallen for someone who's very much like me and I think we
all do that and I think it's particularly tends to happen when people reach middle age and they're realizing
that either they don't have children or that their own children wonderful that though they are in fact aren't mini mes
they're they're not doing what their parents did and I think the parents sort of gravitate towards younger versions of
themselves and they are the ones who they tend to promote and take through the ranks um and it's not an evil thing
at all but I think it's one of these very powerful patterns by which organizations replicate themselves and
as a result of which it makes very hard to get true diversity um the third piece I want to throw out there is um

do think that women on average and in the aggregate do tend to manage
differently than men women tend to be less competitive in terms of putting themselves forward they tend to be less
loud in terms of touting their own successes they tend to favor consensus
again none of which are good or bad they're just different so if if you're
and again I see this at Barnard Barnard is a place that runs on love um and you know we won't do anything until we have
consensus so if you have if you introduce a man or a woman who is used
to moving faster the organization will kind of push that person to the

just and again I really I honestly don't think it's better or worse but it's different and which means if you put a

the rules unless she really conforms or adapts to a very different mindset um
one of the first people I hired at barard was a very just he's a very male guy um and you

have babies men don't that is not going to change and this is a very very
important aspect of kind of everything related to gender differences because if you look at the data women fall out of
the pipeline when they have children and men don't and we have both
societally and even legally the way we've structured things like family leaves we family leaves as you may know
are structured as sick leaves they are to take care of a medical condition known as
pregnancy but having a child is not just a medical condition it is an extended
multi-year commitment and at some level the length of your maternity leave really doesn't make a difference what
happens makes a difference is everything subsequent to that and I think unless we wrestle with this reality we're never
actually going to get at the core of the gender differences we're seeing in the workplace so let me just leave those out
